articles.headline: Biden’s Afghan Pullout Is a Victory for Pakistan. But at What Cost?
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s military stayed allied to both the Americans and Taliban. But now the country may face intensified extremism at home as a result of a perceived Taliban victory.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s military stayed allied to both the Americans and Taliban. But now the country may face intensified extremism at home as a result of a perceived Taliban victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: Near the peak of the American war in Afghanistan, a former chief of neighboring Pakistan’s military intelligence — an institution allied both to the U.S. military and to its Taliban adversaries — appeared on a talk show called “Joke Night” in 2014. He put a bold prediction on the record.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman

articles.headline: Signs of Economic Hope Are Growing, Some With Superlatives
articles.snippet: Soaring retail sales and a sharp drop in jobless claims are the latest reflection of a quickening recovery and suggest a year of remarkable growth.
articles.abstract: Soaring retail sales and a sharp drop in jobless claims are the latest reflection of a quickening recovery and suggest a year of remarkable growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economic recovery is gathering steam, renewing confidence that a vibrant revival awaits as the pandemic recedes.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember, Michael Corkery and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: How the G.O.P. Lost Its Clear Voice on Foreign Policy
articles.snippet: After four years of Donald J. Trump’s America-first mantra, Republican views on foreign intervention, long a signature part of the party’s brand, have splintered.
articles.abstract: After four years of Donald J. Trump’s America-first mantra, Republican views on foreign intervention, long a signature part of the party’s brand, have splintered.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Senator Lindsey Graham traveled the world with his friend John McCain, visiting war zones and meeting with foreign allies and adversaries, before returning home to promote the Republican gospel of an internationalist, hawkish foreign policy.

articles.headline: Derek Chauvin Declines to Testify as His Defense Ends After 2 Days
articles.snippet: The jury is expected to hear closing arguments on Monday and could deliver a verdict in Mr. Chauvin’s trial next week.
articles.abstract: The jury is expected to hear closing arguments on Monday and could deliver a verdict in Mr. Chauvin’s trial next week.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan, John Eligon and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Treasury Puts Taiwan on Notice in Currency Report but Strikes Measured Tone
articles.snippet: The Biden administration removed Vietnam and Switzerland from the list of currency manipulators, but it will push all three countries to address its concerns.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration removed Vietnam and Switzerland from the list of currency manipulators, but it will push all three countries to address its concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said on Friday that it was putting Taiwan, Vietnam and Switzerland on notice over their currency practices, but it struck a more conciliatory tone than the Trump administration by stopping short of labeling any of them a currency manipulator.

articles.headline: A Partial List of Mass Shootings in the United States in 2021
articles.snippet: The shootings never stopped during the coronavirus pandemic, they just became less public, researchers say.
articles.abstract: The shootings never stopped during the coronavirus pandemic, they just became less public, researchers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: To some, it might have seemed as if mass shootings all but halted during the coronavirus pandemic, with a year passing between large-scale shootings in public places.
articles.byline: By Daniel Victor and Derrick Bryson Taylor

articles.headline: Why Amazon Workers Sided With the Company Over a Union
articles.snippet: Pay, benefits and an aggressive anti-union campaign by the company helped generate votes at a warehouse in Alabama.
articles.abstract: Pay, benefits and an aggressive anti-union campaign by the company helped generate votes at a warehouse in Alabama.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Graham Brooks received his ballot in early February, asking whether he wanted to form a union at the Amazon warehouse in Alabama where he works, he did not hesitate. He marked the NO box, and mailed the ballot in.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: How Will Britain Defend Its Financial Fief After Brexit?
articles.snippet: Other European cities are eating away at Britain’s edge in financial services. The government is trying to find ways to keep it.
articles.abstract: Other European cities are eating away at Britain’s edge in financial services. The government is trying to find ways to keep it.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Coming out of Brexit this year, Britain’s government needed a new blueprint for the future of the nation’s financial services as cities like Amsterdam and Paris vied to become Europe’s next capital of investment and banking.
